review.title: Using MathML to Represent Units of Measurement for Improved Ontology Alignment
review.abstract: Ontologies provide a formal description of concepts and their relationships in a knowledge domain. The goal of ontology alignment is to identify semantically matching concepts and relationships across independently developed ontologies that purport to describe the same knowledge. In order to handle the widest possible class of ontologies, many alignment algorithms rely on terminological and structural meth- ods, but the often fuzzy nature of concepts complicates the matching process. However, one area that should provide clear matching solutions due to its mathematical nature, is units of measurement. Several on- tologies for units of measurement are available, but there has been no attempt to align them, notwithstanding the obvious importance for tech- nical interoperability. We propose a general strategy to map these (and similar) ontologies by introducing MathML to accurately capture the semantic description of concepts specified therein. We provide mapping results for three ontologies, and show that our approach improves on lexical comparisons.

sections.heading: 3.1 Minimum Prior Knowledge
sections.text: As already mentioned, all units can be described both in SI base units and in derived units, which in turn can be expressed in base units. Therefore, it can be concluded that all units can be described on the basis of the seven SI base units: meters, kilograms, kelvin, seconds, candela, amperes and moles. Therefore, to assign two unit ontologies, only the SI base units need to be compared as a starting point. This is the minimum requirement for processing the MathML labels. Our general approach assumes that the conversion values of the units are always relative to the SI base units and this is reflected in the MathML comparison. If two units of measurement are to be compared ontologies, the user must provide a first comparison between the base units found in each ontology.

sections.heading: 3.2 Generation and Insertion of MathML
sections.text: The difficulty of creating MathML and inserting it into an existing ontology depends on the structure of the ontology and what information is present in it. For example, different ontologies will use different properties to indicate that one unit is the quotient of two other units. However, given a well-structured ontology that is consistent in its representation of the units, a repeatable pattern will emerge where the necessary information for the MathML encoding can be found. A program can be written to automatically process these patterns and transform them into MathML code. We have inserted MathML into three existing ontologies, one of which will be examined more closely later, but in the end the effort of inserting MathML will vary from ontology to ontology. For the purposes of our approach, the MathML only needs to be inserted so that it is accessible to our matchers.

sections.heading: 5 Results
sections.text: To evaluate our approaches, we have manually aligned the ontologies for comparison (referred to as Reference Units). Following the OAEI comparisons, we calculate the precision, callback and F measurement. Therefore, we use Alignment API version 4.4 to compare the generated alignments with the reference values. sections.heading: 6 Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: We have shown that in the field of ontologies, MathML can be used to better represent the semantics of the units to compare them between ontologies. The alignments generated provide good precision and retrieval values compared to manually generated reference alignments. In future work, we intend to improve the results by further testing to ensure that the matching units are both conceptually and mathematically correct. Furthermore, it will be interesting to combine this approach with other methods of ontological alignment. For example, MathML matching can be used as the first match in combination with lexical comparisons for non-mathematical concepts. This initial mapping is then fed into an algorithm that takes structural similarities between the two ontologies into account in order to build on the original matching.
